title: #298 Data Storytelling Skills for Impact | Kat Greenbrook, Author of The Data Storyteller's Handbook

rawLines.text: welcome to dataf framed This is Richie
If you've ever tried to explain
something with data and your audience
started dozing off then you need data
storytelling It's a really effective way
to keep your audience interested and get
your point across I'm a great believer
that learning to tell data stories is
one of the highest impact skills you can
learn Today we're going to get tips on
how to tell a great data story Cat
Greenbrook is the author of the
best-selling data storytellers handbook
She also runs the Rogue Penguin Data
Storytelling and Business Communication
Consultancy Let's hear Cat's story
There's quite a few things that can make
a good data story A lot of that depends
on who your audience is and what are
they interested in It's got to be
relevant You could write a really
interesting data story for yourself but
if you're giving it to people who aren't
interested in that topic or that data
it's not going to be classed by them as
a good data story right you've got to
think about how it's going to resonate
with your audience
Hi Cat welcome to the show Thank you for
having me I'm looking forward to it Cool
So to begin with what's the greatest
data story you've ever heard that that
is a tough question and I'm going to
sidely I know No pressure Uh I I'm not
going to share the the greatest data
story because that's that's way too much
pressure Uh but I will share some data
storytellers though whose work I think
is amazing I really admire the work of
Daisy Chung She does some really
beautiful scroll retelling She's done a
piece that pops her mind on fentinel and
she gets into the chemistry of it It's
very it seems very technical but the way
that she writes it is just so accessible
and approachable I think it's it goes
with her beautiful illustrations to make
it more engaging And I I love reading
her her pieces I really admire the work
of John Burn Murdoch I don't know if
you've come across his work before He
works for the Financial Times I came
across his work during co so he was
posting on Twitter at the time and
sharing all these graphs but also
weaving the context and the meaning
behind them in the way that he told them
and at that time it was very very
powerful because it was what people
needed to to understand that kind of
information So greatly respect him as a
data storyteller I think a lot of the
data storytelling that seems to make it
into the public domain is coming from
these these media uh outlets or news
outlets because that's generally has
been historically the domain And now
that some of these journalists are
upskilling in data they're combining
what they know about people and
narrative and story uh with data and
those are producing some really really
beautiful data storytelling pieces I
think a lot of the the more traditional
people that work in BI they work for
companies and they're not necessarily
allowed to share a lot of the work that
they do So their data storytelling
doesn't necessarily make it into public
domain And so what we see and what we
read about are being produced by these
data journalists That's interesting that
you've got data journalists and business
intelligence analysts doing I guess
similar things or maybe different styles
of data storytelling but you only kind
of get to see one side of the things
It's a bit more public So you mentioned
a term scrolltyelling I've not come
across that before Tell me what this is
and how you might make use of it Yeah
scrollty telling is just making use of
of scrolling on websites And so you you
start from the top and you scroll down
and as you scroll down the story unfolds
whether that's in a in a visual sense so
you can have interactive things moving
and popping up as you scroll along uh or
just the narrative advances So it is
it's just a fancy term for scroll down
Okay Uh that that seems straightforward
and very useful because I guess a lot of
stories are consumed on the web and you
want to have an experience that goes
alongside that rather than I guess
flipping pages in a book Okay So uh do
you have any more sense of like what
makes these things great you mentioned a
few data journalists there What's sort
of the essence that makes the data
stories great yeah there's there's
there's quite a few things that can make
a good data story and a lot of that
depends on who your audience is and so
what are they interested in it's got to
be relevant So you could write a really
interesting data story for yourself but
if you're giving it to people who aren't
interested in that topic or that data
it's it's not going to be classed by
them as a good data story right and so
you've got to you've got to think about
how it's going to resonate with your
audience A lot of data stories that kind
of go viral are the ones that are quite
topical for what's going on within the
political landscape or within the social
landscape whatever it is But they they
generally are something that the
audience can relate to and the audience
care about And also they have a good
structure to how the information is
presented So they're not just throwing a
whole lot of data at people and
expecting them to kind of piece it
together they've done all that hard work
for the audience and so the audience can
actually just enjoy absorbing the
information because it's already
presented in a way that they can Okay So
I like the idea of doing a bit more in
the sort of content creation side and
then making it easier for the audience
So I'd love to get into some of the
details around this So I know in your
book you have this idea of it's uh the
problem goal action impact framework
which is to help you do this uh talk me
through what is this framework and how
do you use it yeah so this is the very
very basics of how a business should
kind of operate You have a problem that
is trying to be solved and problems and
opportunity go hand in hand So you could
also have an opportunity that you're
trying to grasp Uh from that you set a
goal uh whether that goal is to fix the
problem or take advantage of the
opportunity In order to achieve that
goal though you have to do something you
have to do some sort of action and from
that action you would hope that as well
as achieving the goal you create some
sort of positive business impact because
that's what we're all trying to create
in the jobs that we do We want to leave
a positive impact in the organization
that we're working with So that's the
basic structure of how you work
Everything you do in your job is an
action of some sort that is hopefully
going to achieve a goal and to solve a
problem or create create an opportunity
and that action is going to drive a
positive impact But unfortunately most
of the time we don't know anything more
really than the action that we're doing
because we've been told to do it So just
taking the time to think about okay I'm
doing this piece of work What is my goal
for this piece of work what problem
within the business am I solving what
action am I creating further upstream
that is going to produce a positive
impact from the work that I do and
having this understanding of the problem
the goal the action the impact the
hierarchy in which that we're existing
it can help when we share the work that
we do So we are able to influence better
We are able to share more of the context
around the work that we do We're not
just sharing hey I'm building this model
We're sharing this is the problem that
the business have that this model is
going to solve and the flow on effect
from that is that I'm going to create
this positive impact that's going to be
good for the business But we just don't
really take the time A lot of in the
situations that we work with we don't
understand those problems and goals and
impact of the work that we do We just
understand the action that we take Yeah
I can certainly see how I've built this
model
it's not going to make a lot of sense to
many of your colleagues or certainly
people you're not working with directly
if you don't provide that extra context
So I like that idea of like well figure
out like what problem you're trying to
solve even before you before you're
doing any work and then at the end of it
you got to try and figure out like well
what's the impact of my work in fact it
sounds like this goes beyond data
storytelling even to it's like it's
probably a good idea to think about a
lot of these things for any kind of work
you're doing Okay cool uh do you have
like a concrete example of how you might
put this into action i mean we could we
could go with that that kind of model
example Let's say you're an analyst and
you've worked on a model that's going to
analyze customer churn or you've done
some analysis around why customers are
leaving the organization and you might
think okay I'm just going to share the
results of that the output of my model
But you can frame it using the problem
and the goal and your action and the
impact you hope to create in a way
that's actually going to engage people
Think of it as kind of like an elevator
pitch for the work that you do So you
could say something like our
organization has struggled with
increased customer churn for at least 18
months But I'm analyzing these customers
to understand why they're leaving us And
as a result of my work I hope to add
value to our organization uh through the
use of better retention strategies So
just including some of those downstream
and upstream things problem and impact
you can just weave a little bit more
context around this very very sometimes
technical and specific action that
you're working on and more people will
be able to understand and realize the
value of the work that you do Okay that
makes a lot of sense So it's like what
happens kind of upstream and downstream
from it It's just all all around the
problem is just given that sort of uh
the business cushioning I guess So when
do you bring it into your workflow is
this something you think about like
after you've done your analysis it's
like well how do I now present this to a
group or is it something you need to
think about before you even start
analyzing data it can be both So you can
think about this kind of thing before
you do the analysis So it can be you can
use data storytelling to help share the
results of something that you've done or
you can use data storytelling to help
influence an action that you are about
to do So data stories revolve around
business actions as a way of sharing
them or influencing them And so un
having an understanding of your problem
goal action impact before you go to do
the analysis can help you influence that
buy in So it can help you actually get
that piece of analysis or whatever
action it is off the ground And if
you're sharing the results of something
you've already done you can use the
problem go action impact to help weave
that context into the way that you
explain the importance of the work that
you've done Okay I like that And so it's
it feels like this is fairly flexible in
terms of when you make use of this Like
sometimes you're going to want to like
think about like the whole story
beforehand sometimes afterwards
sometimes I guess it comes up in the
middle So it seems like it's a sort of
like a parallel task to the actual
analysis Yeah I think this is just about
understanding the world in which you're
working in So that could be a business
world that could be a scientific field
whatever world that you're finding
yourself in Having an understanding of
what problem you're solving and what
influence and what impact you're trying
to create is a good thing regardless of
whether you're doing data storytelling
or not Now um I'd like to talk a bit
about tailoring your story to different
audiences because it seems like if
you're speaking to a business person or
speaking to a scientific person or the
technical person it's going to be you're
going with a very different story So do
you have any examples of how you might
want to tailor your data stories to
different audiences it it's it can be
very specific to some audiences So you
could have the same output from piece of
work that you've done and you would have
to produce two different data stories to
meet the needs of two different audience
groups Uh going back to the example we
talked about analyzing customer churn
You could say that your initial audience
might be your boss might be your manager
and you could show them what you found
in terms of this is what's happening Uh
but you could also you need to think
about their motivations what they care
about And probably for someone in that
position they're going to want to know
did you go through very accurate u data
analysis process in terms of I don't
want anything being shared from this
team unless it's really accurate because
it's going to come back and and bite
your boss right so your boss is going to
be very very concerned about if anything
goes outside their team it needs to be
have gone through a very robust analysis
process So they're going to be focused
on that But if you were sharing that
insight with say the marketing team they
will want to know what happened Yes But
they will also have a focus on the
future What's going to happen in the
future so they probably don't care about
how accurate your analysis is They trust
you They trust the position that you
have within the company You're you're
employed because you're good at that So
they that's not a concern for them They
don't care about how you've done the
analysis They just care about what it
means for them going forward and how
they can use it to make their jobs
easier So it all comes down to audience
motivations and what what they care
about because you really have to think
about that in terms of what you
communicate If you were to go and
communicate an a very in-depth playbook
about how you've done the analysis to a
marketing team you're going to bore the
hell out of them So it's just being very
very aware of what it is that your
audience care about and also how much
technical detail they need So your boss
is probably going to be very interested
in the technical detail Your colleagues
are going to be interested in the
technical detail if if you're a data an
analyst uh but anybody probably outside
the data team is not not going to need
those technical details You're going to
drown them in information that they
they're not interested in So you have to
be aware of what interests your audience
I say the story hits home quite hard I

I would recommend doing two different

So just sometimes thinking about how

it's going to resonate differently with

So imagine like talking to your team or

about what their preferences are going
to be Are they going to like a lot of

have to ask yourself some of those

okay my audience is kind of sitting over
here I I I think they're going to prefer
a more summarized format Generally if
you go out from the away from the
technical detail into a more public
audience they're going to prefer a lot
more context and far less jargon So you
have to think about how much technical
detail does your audience prefer And if
they are working in a technical space
then maybe that's okay But even some
technical spaces don't understand
certain jargon terms that maybe you're
very familiar with and you you don't
even think about anymore Sometimes we
fall under a what's called a curse of
knowledge where you forget what it's
like to not know the information and so
therefore you just communicate with at
your current level of knowledge and
forget that other people don't have that
Uh so I like to when I'm going to a
general audience whether it's if you're

in your company start with the person
who has just joined the company So
they've just joined this on today
They've just joined the company You're

going to lose them You mentioned uh the

you've got a lot of numbers uh technical

whether your audience needs to
understand those technical details
because most of the time they don't
Especially when you're talking about

I think that's the first question you

Okay So really just include I guess the

Just don't start out with it I like the

you you've got the evidence to to back

the subject of tailoring things I know
in your book you've got um different
sort of archetypes of stories So you got
I think you mentioned the one about like
character data story and what about a
time data story Just talk me through
what are these different types and when
you might use them Yeah So these are the
two main types in which you would
actually contrast data measurements So
data stories are built around how you
can contrast your data measurements So a
time data story uses time as a way of
contrasting these measurements So it it
looks at okay last year we had this
expenditure but this year we have this
expenditure So we're using the
difference in time to contrast that data
measurement And character data stories
look at how these data measurements are
different across different characters
And a character in a data story is not
like a fictional character from a book A
character in a data story is generally
whatever the data is describing And so
it can be a company it can be a product
it be an animal uh it could be a person
So a character data story character data
story contrast looks at okay our
business did this this year but our
competitor did this and so we're using
uh different characters to contrast our
data measurements and contrast in in
storytelling in general is very
important stories are built around
contrast and data contrast is just
another way in which we can add that
contrast into our storytelling So moving
on from tailoring to structure I think
like there are a lot of kind of standard
story structures So there's like the
hero's journey and all these kind of
things I'm not sure which ones of these
are applicable to like a business
analytics scenario Um what sort of
structures do you think work for data
stories yeah basically I mean any story
structure can work for a data story I
I'm familiar with a hero's journey I I
think it's a bit too involved for a data
story especially the data stories that
are used within business as just a way
of general communication They don't have
to be that detailed They don't have to
be that hard to do I like to use the and
but therefore narrative structure which
is basically a form of the threeact
structure just to make sure that you
include those three acts in terms of how
you present information So making sure
that you have your act one there to set
the scene to provide that context You
have your act two there Generally it can
go into what is the problem we're
solving what is what are we banging up
against what are we finding hard what's
our struggle and then act three this is
what we're going to do about it This is
our conclusion our resolution whatever
it is But those three acts hitting those
points creates a a full story It's not
just a case of sharing random numbers
without a structure Having a story
structure in place is the backbone of
your data storytelling So yeah there are
really complex structures out there Um
the hero's journey one of them Uh I just
don't think it's that amount of detail
is necessary for business communication
Okay So I like that sort of simple idea
So let me see It was what there was a
scene setting and then some sort of
tension or problem and then some sort of
hopefully happy ending I guess in act
three Um can you talk me through like an
example of how the three acts work for a

give you an example of how it works just
in general storytelling and I can give
you an example of how we've in data
storytelling Uh I've got a an example
here for general storytelling I'll just
I'll just read it off because I'm not
going to remember this word for word but
it's a it's an and but therefore So they
use the words and but and therefore to
define those three acts Uh and see if
you can guess the movie I've It's based
on a movie plot line so I've made it

young mermaid princess who dreams of

falls deeply in love with him But her
father King Triton forbids any contact
with humans Desperate to be with Eric
Ariel makes a deal with the sea witch
Ursula who grants her legs in exchange
for her voice Therefore Ariel embarks on
a quest for love and her life in the
human world All right Yes Uh this uh
Ariel the little mermaid It was uh I
like that cartoon when I was a kid It's
like ginger protagonist Uh it's good
stuff Go on Uh and what's the So those
are the three acts And so the words the
word and helps join together statements
in the first act to provide that context
So they're all the statement and is the
most common agreement word They're all
these statements that you join together
in the first act They're all in
agreement uh they're all helping to set
the scene introduce the character and
but introduces the second act because
it's a contrast word So it's it's
providing that tension between act one
and act two So when King Triton forbids
any contact with human that's that's the
tension of the story And therefore helps
resolve the tension that was introduced
in act two So we're introducing act
three with the word therefore and
continuing the story on in a way that's
going to conclude it And we can do the
same with our data stories just by using
these three words And I'll give you a
very very simple example but you could
say last year we had 20,000 customers
and held a large proportion of the
market share But this year customer
numbers dropped 25% because of increased
competitor activity Therefore we need to
think about how we are going to win back
our
customers So that's an example of a data
story I don't think it has to be as
involved as the the hero's journey
structure It can be simply these three
acts but making sure that we have
something for our for each act will help
us to tell a more balanced story Okay
And this sounds like it's going to feed
naturally into that understanding what
your problem is from the the previous
PGAI framework we've talked about Yeah
So having having an idea of the problem
that your action is actually solving uh
will definitely help in terms of how you
put that story together because it can
weave through some of that context for
your audience Do you always want these
three acts or do you ever want to like
break your story down into smaller
building blocks so I always start with
with the three acts And the more general
you can make it the better because then
you can start to go deeper if your
audience needs a little bit more detail
And so I call these nested stories or
stories within stories And so if you
have a problem statement for your second
act and you find your audience is

information about that problem more than
just maybe a sentence or two then you
can actually create another ABT
structure or a story within a story that

you can flesh out your highle stories
but still keep them engaging so you're
not just throwing a whole lot of
information at people Okay Stories
within stories I I can imagine this

sort of inception type situation Lots of

like three sentences with story isn't
going to be enough for some people when
they want more detail Yeah you'll be
surprised though because I think it's
it's actually enough for a lot of people
uh there there'll be times when you

for the majority of situations in a

away with just that high level story
Okay Yeah But if you're like presenting

I guess the other thing with stories is
how you make sure that um the story is
an honest representation of the data
because it's very easy to kind of you
know massage the the results to fit your
story rather than the other way around
So how do you stay honest yeah and this
is a good question because storytelling
I think gets a bad name in terms of
people don't trust it because they do
think of it as something that is made up
something that people use to manipulate
other people and that's absolutely true
People do make up stories and people do
use the engagement of stories to
manipulate other people There's I'm no
denying that But I think they use it
because it is so powerful And if people
can start to use it to present facts
present honest data then it can be just
as powerful in resonating and
influencing them Uh but there does come
ethical decisions and things that you
have to make along the way if you call
yourself a data storyteller So you have
to make sure that your source is
reputable You have to check your own
biases So are there conflicts of
interest that maybe you have in terms of
how you interpret the the data and how
you communicate that data uh it helps to
understand any assumptions that you're
making So assumptions are fine to make I
think when doing data analysis Uh
sometimes we have to make assumptions
but just understanding why you've made
them So looking at correlations versus
causation uh data accuracy have you made
assumptions around that that maybe just
writing down will will help you actually
readress and think okay is that right or
even just asking another person do you
think this is right for me to have made
this assumption and also when you are
writing a story ask yourself what is the
counter story and is that true because
data can tell different stories based on
the context in which it's examined So
you could be looking at a specific
number and if you compare that number to
a higher number it seems lower but if
you compare it to a lower number it
seems higher So you can kind of shift
how people
um respond to that particular number
that you're sharing whether it's in a
good or bad way sometimes So you really
have to think about yes I'm pushing this
particular narrative but is another
narrative also true that could
contradict this one and you have to be
comfortable with data holding multiple
truths and how you communicate that can
sometimes be quite difficult because you
have to communicate those multiple
truths Oh man that it was it was
starting to sound quite simple like you
just need to make sure that you've got
these shakes in place to make sure your
analysis is kind of uh correct and that
your conclusions are valid and then just
try and communicate this as accurately
as you can but then the idea that you
got multiple truths within data so you
might have to communicate things in a
different way Um how do you reconcile
that like what's the good way actually
first of all do you have an example of
this and then how do you go about
communicating like the these different
sort of truths yeah I think the
different sort of truths um I don't have
a concrete example in my head right now
but it it could be just in the
perception of your the perception your
audience has of particular data And so
you could have um let's say the dairy
industry Uh you could have people from
the the vegan side of things and who see
the truth of the dairy industry in a
very negative way in terms of
environmental damage You can see another
camp of people looking at the dairy
industry and thinking they're supplying
food to the world This is a very
positive positive thing Both of those
things can be true
and it's finding a balance between you
don't want to necessarily just show one
